I really dug the gameplay loop during the six hours I played. The core mechanic involves testing out different combinations with the deck-building cards, removing weaker ones, and growing stronger to be able to face the final boss. Doing a run usually takes about 15–30 minutes, making it quick and fun. A unique aspect of Monster Train is that you must defend your pyre at the top of a train on three different floors while the enemies ascend.

Monster Train is the best roguelike I have played. The fast paced combat, constant learning and growing, tons of viable strategies, and consistent gameplay loop made its way into my heart.
It took me 84 hours to complete every achievement, only using a guide for two of them (How to Deckbuilder and Covenant 25 Infernal).

The real genius comes in the form of the clan system, where you get to pick two different clans and have both cards, allowing you to find interesting and unique synergies between the cards. Infernal's self damaging spell being turned into viable kill options on enemies with Stygian Guard's spell power or turns them into sac outlets for Melting Remnant on death effects. It all works together.

The DLC is fantastic, adding in a new final boss that is very interesting to play around and is unique. A new clan with tons of unique mechanics and synergies. And a more robust difficulty system where you can choose to get more powerful rewards for increased difficulty throughout the run.

Gameplay: 10/10, the best deckbuilding I have seen with upgrading your cards with unique tokens. The Tower defense type battle system. The close calls where every point of damage matters. The times you get overpowered, but you actually have to work for the victory still.
Story: 7/10. Most of the story is background lore, and I appreciate it a lot more while playing through the sequel.
Graphics: 9/10. I love the art style is the game. Every blends well together and it sets the tone for the game.
Sound: 7/10. The music is very good, the sound effects get a bit much, but I do like the OST.
Difficulty: 6/10. Not very difficult, but it builds perfectly and each covenant rank increases in difficulty at the same rate you are getting better. The later covenant ranks add to the depth of the game mechanics rather than taking them away.

Overall: 9/10

Monster Train is a very, very good game. It's inferior in most aspects to Slay the Spire, although not in all. Design wise it's heavily leaning toward combinations - less cards per ensemble, but out of the box ability to combine two ensemble that is not just a quasi-gimmick like the prismatic shard in Slay the Spire but actually designed for that. Similarly the playing board has extra dimensions - floors, numbers of entities on both sides - while the card play itself is more limited (although still very much existent and deep). Art is nothing remarquable although it's reasonably pleasant. Music is catchy. While I prefer StS on all of those aspects, it's a matter of taste. What is not though is the fact that the UI is way less polished/well thought than Slay the Spire, by far my biggest issue with the game. It's nothing disastrous but coming from StS, oof. Issues include inability to see the whole board at once (for no reasons other than aresthetic at the -severe- expense of clarity and responsiveness - a major crime shared by Inkulinati, who thinks those constant zoom in zoom out are any good? Jesus.), discard UI that has the wrong trajectory for card pick making discarding the wrong one the default results if you don't circle around things, an enthousiasm for playing card you released 34 thousands mile away from away from a floor after deciding you didn't want to play it on that floor (which it absolutely will nonetheless). In general they were many other things that could have been done but weren't so that the information was less bloated. Lots of numbers without bars, lack of hierarchy in the tool tips... make it very easy to miss informations and give up on learning by the game rule, instead just trying stuff. Which is... doable but StS precisely shown that you could be *actually playing* the game from the first minute, having all the information you need to make decisions. 

It does share a cons with StS which is no undo/restart the fight but it's vastly more problematic because of the above, the facts that a lot of the time you have to play shit to simply get the rule the tool tip wasn't 100% clear about etc. Nothing bad in itself but it's a bit dumb to have to quit to the main menu en re enter the game to restart it. 
While this all may sound negative let me reiterate this is down the line a brilliant game though. It's *extremely* catchy, packed with interesting mechanics and a solid execution of those. The cost in money is nothing here, it's more about how willing you are to put your finger in the cogs and get eaten by the game. Although from what I understand the endgame isn't eternal like StS, but it sure is hundreds of hours of great fun. Unquestionably worth buying.
